articles.title: First Unique Character in a String Solution
Multiple Approaches to Find First Unique Character

patternTriggers: Use Hash Table/Frequency Count pattern when you need to track character occurrences and find first/last unique element. Key indicators: need to count frequencies, find first occurrence of something, checking uniqueness, single pass with lookup needed.

approaches.name: Brute Force - Nested Loop
approaches.intuition: For each character, check if it appears again anywhere else in the string. The first character that doesn't appear again is the answer.
approaches.approach: Iterate through each character and use a nested loop to count how many times it appears in the entire string. Return the index of the first character with count 1.
steps: Iterate through string with index i from 0 to n-1
For each character at index i, initialize count = 0
Use nested loop with index j from 0 to n-1
Count how many times s[i] appears in entire string
If count equals 1, return index i
If loop completes without finding unique character, return -1

complexity.timeExplanation: For each of n characters, we scan entire string of length n
complexity.spaceExplanation: Only using counter variable, no additional data structures

approaches.name: Hash Map - Two Pass (Optimal)
approaches.intuition: Count frequency of each character first, then iterate through the string again to find the first character with frequency 1. This avoids redundant counting.
approaches.approach: Use a hash map to count frequency of all characters in first pass. In second pass, find the first character whose frequency is 1.
steps: Create hash map to store character frequencies
First pass: iterate through string and count frequency of each character
Second pass: iterate through string again
For each character, check if its frequency is 1
Return index of first character with frequency 1
If no unique character found, return -1

complexity.timeExplanation: Two passes through string: O(n) + O(n) = O(n)
complexity.spaceExplanation: Hash map stores at most 26 lowercase letters (or 52 for case-sensitive), which is O(1)

approaches.name: Array as Hash Table (Space Optimized)
approaches.intuition: If we know the character set is limited (e.g., only lowercase letters), we can use an array instead of hash map for better space efficiency and faster access.
approaches.approach: Use a fixed-size array (26 for lowercase letters) as a hash table. Map each character to an index using 'c - a'. Count frequencies, then find first unique character.
steps: Create array of size 26 (for lowercase a-z) initialized to 0
First pass: for each character, increment freq[c - 'a']
Second pass: for each character, check if freq[c - 'a'] == 1
Return index of first character with frequency 1
If no unique character exists, return -1

complexity.timeExplanation: Two passes through string of length n
complexity.spaceExplanation: Array of fixed size 26, which is O(1)

commonMistakes: Returning the character instead of its index
Not handling the case when no unique character exists (should return -1)
Using single pass with checking previous characters only (misses duplicates after current position)
Not considering case sensitivity if problem requires it
Forgetting that we need the FIRST unique character, not just any unique character
Using indexOf and lastIndexOf incorrectly to check uniqueness
Off-by-one errors when using array indices for character mapping
hints: You need to count how many times each character appears in the string
The first pass should count frequencies, the second pass should find the answer
Think about using a hash map to store character frequencies
For lowercase English letters only, you can use an array of size 26 instead of a hash map
Remember to return the index, not the character itself
